text: hello my name is Brian Anderson and I'm
here with my colleague Nick Dentry both
coming to you from the enterprise
solutions architect space here at
AWS today we wanted to take some time to
talk to you about how to get started
with Amazon Q developer
CLI first we'll set up the Amazon Q
developer pro tier within the AWS
console this will involve creating an IM
identity center instance creating an SSO
user and creating the Amazon Q developer
application and developer
profile next we'll install the Amazon Q
developer CLI and log in with our
ProTier
account let's get
started today I'm going to show you how
you can set up Amazon Q developer Pro
within a brand new AWS account first
we'll start by navigating to the Amazon
Q developer console page amazon Q
developer requires integration with AM
identity center to control which users
and groups have an active subscription
to the Q developer application since
this is a brand new account and I have
not set up IM identity center previously
the getting started button here will
prompt me for user information so I can
one create an IM identity center
instance in this account two add a new
SSO user to the identity center instance
and three set up a developer profile
that the new account will have access to
that will enable my Q developer Pro
subscription when I hit create I will be
sent an email with instructions on
finishing the setup of my account
now that I've completed this initial
setup I'll quickly show you how the AM
identity center instance was created by
navigating to the console page for this
service as you can see my new user
account has been created and when I
navigate to the application section
you'll see the Q developer application
was created along with my user account
that has been associated with this
application
clicking on the setup link from the
email I received I can now finish the
setup of my account by setting a new
password and logging in to show the
account setup was successful for
security reasons I'll skip over the MFA
setup
portion since this identity center
instance is an account instance and not
an organization instance my user only
has access to the application it is
assigned to and not any other AWS
accounts which is why you'll see me get
redirected to the Amazon Q product
page now that I've successfully
configured the Amazon Q developer
application and our user account I'm
going to show you how we can install the
Amazon Q developer CLI since I am on a
Mac I will use the installation
instructions for Mac OS but please
follow the instructions for whichever
operating system you are using the link
to the Amazon Q developer documentation
will be provided in the video
description for those following
along for ease of use I chose to install
the Q developer CLI through the Home
Brew package manager to verify that it
was installed correctly I'll follow the
instructions to check that I get a
result from querying the tool for its
version after successful installation
I'll launch the Amazon Q developer
application which was installed to my
applications folder as part of the
installation
since we want to use the CLI with our
pro subscription I'll navigate back to
the AM identity center console page and
copy the start URL that users of this
instance use to authenticate with
applications owned by the identity
center
instance i'll likewise ensure that the
region matches the region where my
developer profile was created
i'll also include a link in the
description to the supported regions
page for the Amazon Q developer
profile next I'll allow access to the
application through the sign-in flow to
ensure that the QLI launches with every
new shell session some hooks can be
added to the scripts that are
automatically sourced when launching new
shell
sessions if you'd prefer not to use the
provided standalone application you can
likewise type Q login in your terminal
to initiate the login
process now that's it you've
successfully set up Amazon Q developer
CLI with a pro subscription and can
start leveraging the power of Amazon Q
right from your terminal window q
developer can provide expert guidance
for building on AWS
the CLI edition provides built-in
tooling for interacting with your shell
with the ability to create and read
files and navigate your file system
create feedback loops by running
applications and fixing error outputs
and is completely extensible with the
new addition of model context protocol
or MCP
support check the documentation for the
latest features and happy coding
